sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving acids and bases
message_1: What is the standard enthalpy change for the reaction between hydrochloric acid (HCl) and potassium hydroxide (KOH) to form potassium chloride (KCl) and water (H2O) at 25°C and 1 atm pressure, given that the standard enthalpy of formation of HCl, KOH, KCl, and H2O are -92.3 kJ/mol, -424.4 kJ/mol, -436.6 kJ/mol, and -285.8 kJ/mol respectively?
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction, we can use the following equation:

ΔH° = Σ ΔHf°(products) - Σ ΔHf°(reactants)

The balanced chemical equation for the reaction is:

HCl (aq) + KOH (aq) → KCl (aq) + H2O (l)

Now, we can plug in the standard enthalpy of formation values for each compound:

ΔH° = [(-436.6 kJ/mol) + (-285.8 kJ/mol)] - [(-92.3 kJ/mol) + (-424.4 kJ/mol)]

ΔH° = (-722.4 kJ/mol) - (-516.7 kJ/mol)

ΔH° = -205.7 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change for the reaction between hydrochloric acid and potassium hydroxide to form potassium chloride and water at 25°C and 1 atm pressure is -205.7 kJ/mol.
